Solving this should be the aim of a positive-dimensional system solver.

html: Can you give any example for positive-dimensional system solver ? I didn't get about this in your proposal. any example will help me.
text: Can you give any example for positive-dimensional system solver ? I didn't get about this in your proposal. any example will help me.

html:
In []: foo =  a+b+c+d
In []: bar = a*b + b*c + c*d + d*a
In []: foo_bar = a*b*c+ b*c*d+ c*d*a + d*a*b 
In []: bar_foo = a*b*c*d- 1
In []: system = [foo, bar, foo_bar, bar_foo]
In []: is_zero_dimensional(system)
Out[]: False

This is a system of positive dimension.
Lazard used this example as his reference for solving a general system of polynomials using triangular decomposition.

I am positive about this example being in my proposal.
Given the length of the proposal, you must have overlooked it. :)
text:
```python
In []: foo =  a+b+c+d
In []: bar = a*b + b*c + c*d + d*a
In []: foo_bar = a*b*c+ b*c*d+ c*d*a + d*a*b 
In []: bar_foo = a*b*c*d- 1
In []: system = [foo, bar, foo_bar, bar_foo]
In []: is_zero_dimensional(system)
Out[]: False
```
This is a  system of positive dimension. 
Lazard used this example as his reference for solving a general system of polynomials using triangular decomposition.

I am positive about this example being in my proposal.
Given the length of the proposal, you must have overlooked it. :)

html:
Also, such a system has infinitely many solution (hence, it is called positive-dimensional)
We can try to find a description of the solutions from which the relevant properties of the solutions are easy to extract.
And to that end, Lazard proposed to use Traingular sets of polynomials.
But if the new matrix method works well, then all is fine :)
text:

We can try to find a description of the solutions from which the relevant properties of the solutions are easy to extract.

But if the new matrix method works well, then all is fine :)

html:
Few doubts about the implementation of transolve:

  1. While solving the given equation, we will need to keep track of all the possible different equations we discover through recursion.
    To me, the simplest way to handle this issue would be to use a global variable (list). What would be some other ways to do the same ?
  2. While developing transolveas an independent solver for solving transcendental equations, I find that almost all the code from _solvesetfunction would need to be copied with some modification. I am bit skeptical of this. Should I look to implement transolve in a similar way to _tsolve i.e. as a helper function to _solveset?

Ping @/all
text:
Few doubts about the implementation of `transolve`:
1. While solving the given equation, we will need to keep track of all the possible different equations we discover through recursion.
To me, the simplest way to handle this issue would be to use a global variable (list). What would be some other ways to do the same ?
2. While developing `transolve`as  an independent solver for solving transcendental equations, I find that almost all the code from `_solveset`function would need to be copied with some modification. I am bit skeptical of this. Should I look to implement `transolve` in a similar way to `_tsolve` i.e. as a helper function to `_solveset`?

Ping @/all

html: @Shekharrajak the dimension of a system is (roughly) the number of variable parameters you need to represent the solution. If you think of a graph, the solution of a one-dimensional system is a line, a two-dimensional system is a surface, and so on (at least for real systems, for complex it is a "complex line" which geometrically is like a real surface). A zero-dimensional system has finite solutions (i.e., just points).
text: @Shekharrajak the dimension of a system is (roughly) the number of variable parameters you need to represent the solution. If you think of a graph, the solution of a one-dimensional system is a line, a two-dimensional system is a surface, and so on (at least for real systems, for complex it is a "complex line" which geometrically is like a real surface). A zero-dimensional system has finite solutions (i.e., just points).

html:
While solving the given equation, we will need to keep track of all the possible different equations we discover through recursion. To me, the simplest way to handle this issue would be to use a global variable (list). What would be some other ways to do the same ?

Global variables should not be used, unless really necessary. The usual way to avoid that is to pass the variable as a state to the parameter to the recursive function, that's what solve did and but should be avoided too because 1. all these parameters makes it hard to keep track of the code. 2. Having parameters doesn't really go well with our future plan to have search based solver.
text:
> While solving the given equation, we will need to keep track of all the possible different equations we discover through recursion. To me, the simplest way to handle this issue would be to use a global variable (list). What would be some other ways to do the same ?

Global variables should not be used, unless **really** necessary. The usual way to avoid that is to pass the variable as a state to the parameter to the recursive function, that's what `solve` did and but should be avoided too because 1. all these parameters makes it hard to keep track of the code. 2. Having parameters doesn't really go well with our future plan to have search based solver.

html:
While developing transolveas an independent solver for solving transcendental equations, I find that almost all the code from _solveset function would need to be copied with some modification. I am bit skeptical of this. Should I look to implement transolve in a similar way to _tsolve i.e. as a helper function to _solveset?

Why doesn't calling solveset work?

html: How to convert an ImageSetto an iterable (preferably a tuple) object ?
text: How to convert an `ImageSet`to an iterable (preferably a `tuple`) object ?

html: @aktech
text: @aktech

html: This seems to work
text: This seems to work

html:
In [31]: tuple(ImageSet(Lambda(x, x**2), FiniteSet(1, 2, 3, 4)))
Out[31]: (1, 4, 9, 16)
text:
```
In [31]: tuple(ImageSet(Lambda(x, x**2), FiniteSet(1, 2, 3, 4)))
Out[31]: (1, 4, 9, 16)
```

html:
Yeah.
This method works fine when the base_set is a FiniteSet.
However, if we try something like the following, the process never stops (at least on my station):
In[] : tuple(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers), )
text:
Yeah. 
This method works fine when the `base_set` is a `FiniteSet`.
However, if we try something like the following, the process never stops (at least on my station):
```python
In[] : tuple(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers), )
```

html: You are trying to convert an infinite set into a tuple, that's not possible.
text: You are trying to convert an infinite set into a tuple, that's not possible.

html: If you want to iterate over an ImageSet you can simply create a generator from it.
text: If you want to iterate over an `ImageSet` you can simply create a generator from it.

html: In [4]: sol = iter(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers))
text:
```python
In [4]: sol = iter(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers))
```

html:
Now use that sol to iterate over that ImageSet
In [22]: for i in sol:
   ....:     print(i)
   ....:     if i > 5: break
   ....:     
-4*pi
6*pi
-6*pi
8*pi
text:
Now use that `sol` to iterate over that `ImageSet`
```python
In [22]: for i in sol:
   ....:     print(i)
   ....:     if i > 5: break
   ....:     
-4*pi
6*pi
-6*pi
8*pi
```

html:
I got it.
(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers), )
This is what I have been looking for
text:
I got it.
```(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers), )
```
This is what I have been looking for

html: Thanks for the help.
text: Thanks for the help.

html:
By the way ImageSet class has its own def __iter__(self) method defined in it, so you can directly iterate over it as well.
In [48]: for i in ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers):
   ....:     print(i)
   ....:     if i > 20: break
   ....:     
0
2*pi
-2*pi
4*pi
-4*pi
6*pi
-6*pi
8*pi
text:
By the way `ImageSet` class has its own `def __iter__(self)` method defined in it, so you can directly iterate over it as well.

```python
In [48]: for i in ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*pi), S.Integers):
   ....:     print(i)
   ....:     if i > 20: break
   ....:     
0
2*pi
-2*pi
4*pi
-4*pi
6*pi
-6*pi
8*pi
```

html:
If the positive dimensional system is 

foo =  a+b+c+d
bar = a*b + b*c + c*d + d*a
foo_bar = a*b*c+ b*c*d+ c*d*a + d*a*b 
bar_foo = a*b*c*d- 1
system = [foo, bar, foo_bar, bar_foo]

Then I am getting output this : 

⎡⎧   1            -1 ⎫                                                                                                                ⎤
⎢⎨a: ─, b: -d, c: ───⎬, {a: -1, b: 1, c: 1, d: -1}, {a: 1, b: -1, c: -1, d: 1}, {a: -ⅈ, b: ⅈ, c: ⅈ, d: -ⅈ}, {a: ⅈ, b: -ⅈ, c: -ⅈ, d: ⅈ}⎥
⎣⎩   d             d ⎭                                                                                                                ⎦

but I think only first one should be returned, right ?
text:
If the positive dimensional system is 
```
foo =  a+b+c+d
bar = a*b + b*c + c*d + d*a
foo_bar = a*b*c+ b*c*d+ c*d*a + d*a*b 
bar_foo = a*b*c*d- 1
system = [foo, bar, foo_bar, bar_foo]
```
Then I am getting output this : 
```
⎡⎧   1            -1 ⎫                                                                                                                ⎤
⎢⎨a: ─, b: -d, c: ───⎬, {a: -1, b: 1, c: 1, d: -1}, {a: 1, b: -1, c: -1, d: 1}, {a: -ⅈ, b: ⅈ, c: ⅈ, d: -ⅈ}, {a: ⅈ, b: -ⅈ, c: -ⅈ, d: ⅈ}⎥
⎣⎩   d             d ⎭                                                                                                                ⎦

```
but I think only first one should be returned, right ?

Out[2]: (-∞, ∞) ∩ {y}

Out[4]: {-y + 2}
In 2nd case Intersection is not expected, right ?

In [5]: is_zero_dimensional([x**2 + 2/y - 2, x + y - 3])
Out[5]: False

In [6]: solve([x**2 + 2/y - 2, x + y - 3])
Out[6]: [{x: 1, y: 2}, {x: 1 + √5, y: -√5 + 2}, {x: -√5 + 1, y: 2 + √5}]
is_zero_dimensional should return True, in this case.
text:
```
In [5]: is_zero_dimensional([x**2 + 2/y - 2, x + y - 3])
Out[5]: False

In [6]: solve([x**2 + 2/y - 2, x + y - 3])
Out[6]: [{x: 1, y: 2}, {x: 1 + √5, y: -√5 + 2}, {x: -√5 + 1, y: 2 + √5}]

```
`is_zero_dimensional` should return `True`, in this case.

In [ ]: factor_list(sqrt(2)*x +1)
Out[ ]: (1, [(√2⋅x + 1, 1)])

In [ ]: factor_list(sqrt(2)*x)
Error PolificationFailed: can't construct a polynomial from 2
It should return (1, [(√2⋅x , 1)]) .
text:
```
In [ ]: factor_list(sqrt(2)*x +1)
Out[ ]: (1, [(√2⋅x + 1, 1)])

In [ ]: factor_list(sqrt(2)*x)
Error PolificationFailed: can't construct a polynomial from 2

```
It should return `(1, [(√2⋅x , 1)])` .

html: The real error is buried. If you use Python 3, it shows it
text: The real error is buried. If you use Python 3, it shows it

html: GeneratorsNeeded: specify generators to give 2 a meaning
text: `GeneratorsNeeded: specify generators to give 2 a meaning`

html: the polys by default treat things like sqrt(2) as generators. So you should use factor_list(sqrt(2)*x, x)
text: the polys by default treat things like `sqrt(2)` as generators. So you should use `factor_list(sqrt(2)*x, x)`

html: even so, the error you found is likely a bug
text: even so, the error you found is likely a bug

need to discuss about this system : 
In [21]: solve([x, y-x-5],[x,y])
Out[21]: {x: 0, y: 5}

In [22]: solve([x, y-x-5],[x])
Out[22]: []

In [23]: solve([t, y-x-5],[x])
Out[23]: {x: y - 5}

In [25]: linsolve([t, y-x-5],[x])
Out[25]: ∅

In [26]: linsolve([t, y-x-5],[y])
Out[26]: ∅

In [27]: solve_poly_system([x-5, y-x-5],[y])

In [28]: solve_poly_system([x-5, y-x-5],[])
Out[28]: [(5, 10)]

In [29]: linsolve([x-5, y-x-5],[y])
Out[29]: ∅

In [30]: linsolve([x-5, y-x-5],[x,y])
Out[30]: {(5, 10)}

In [31]: linsolve([x-5, y-x-5],[x])
Out[31]: ∅
text:
need to discuss about this system : 
```
In [21]: solve([x, y-x-5],[x,y])
Out[21]: {x: 0, y: 5}

In [22]: solve([x, y-x-5],[x])
Out[22]: []

In [23]: solve([t, y-x-5],[x])
Out[23]: {x: y - 5}

In [25]: linsolve([t, y-x-5],[x])
Out[25]: ∅

In [26]: linsolve([t, y-x-5],[y])
Out[26]: ∅

In [27]: solve_poly_system([x-5, y-x-5],[y])

In [28]: solve_poly_system([x-5, y-x-5],[])
Out[28]: [(5, 10)]

In [29]: linsolve([x-5, y-x-5],[y])
Out[29]: ∅

In [30]: linsolve([x-5, y-x-5],[x,y])
Out[30]: {(5, 10)}

In [31]: linsolve([x-5, y-x-5],[x])
Out[31]: ∅

```

Out[61]: ∅
text:

html:
Can we use namedtuple ?
eg.
from collections import namedtuple

Animal = namedtuple('Animal', 'name age type')
perry = Animal(name="perry", age=31, type="cat")
print(perry)
# Output: Animal(name='perry', age=31, type='cat')

print(perry.name)
# Output: 'perry'
text:
Can we use namedtuple ? 
eg.
```
from collections import namedtuple

Animal = namedtuple('Animal', 'name age type')
perry = Animal(name="perry", age=31, type="cat")
print(perry)
# Output: Animal(name='perry', age=31, type='cat')

print(perry.name)
# Output: 'perry'
```

html: I have added some points regarding complete Integer solution using solveset_integer (PR sympy/sympy#11234 ) in week 6 blog . Please have a look.
text: I have added some points regarding complete Integer solution using `solveset_integer` (PR [#11234](https://github.com/sympy/sympy/pull/11234) ) in [week 6 blog](http://shekharrajak.github.io/Coding-Period-week-6/)  . Please have a look.

html:
I discussed about complete solution in diophantine with @thilinarmtb (He have worked on diophantine. Blog link : https://thilinaatsympy.wordpress.com/). Main points are :

Only the linear solver is incomplete, the algorithm in Diophantine module should be fixed (permute_signs or something like that won't help). We can use permute_signs when we have even powers in all variables. We should update Diophantine module to use permute sign. But we should not returns ConditionSet for linear diophantine eq. because for linear diophantine eq diophantine()returns parameterized solution which is complete most of the time.
text:
I discussed about complete solution in `diophantine` with @thilinarmtb (He have worked on `diophantine`. Blog link : [https://thilinaatsympy.wordpress.com/](https://thilinaatsympy.wordpress.com/page/2/)). Main points are :

Only the linear solver is incomplete, the algorithm in Diophantine module should be fixed (`permute_signs` or something like that won't help). We can use `permute_signs` when we have even powers in all variables. We should update Diophantine module to use permute sign. But we should not returns `ConditionSet` for linear diophantine eq. because for linear diophantine eq `diophantine()`returns parameterized solution which is complete most of the time.

html: Great
text: Great

text: Are there ways using which we can verify if the solution to the equation is complete or not?

html: I asked thilinarmtb  , for a example so that I can find more similar linear eq type for which soln is not complete . But he was not able to remember any examples that time. When I asked, should I skip liner eq. he replied, "I think you should still integrate the linear solvers".

html:
In [ ]: Intersection(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*I*pi), S.Integers), S.Complexes)
Out[ ]: {2⋅ⅈ⋅π⋅n | n ∊ ℤ} ∩ ℂ

In [ ]: from sympy.solvers.solveset import  _invert_real
In [ ]: _invert_real(exp(x) + 8,FiniteSet(0), x)
Out[ ]: (x, {log(8) + ⅈ⋅π})
In first case directly {2⋅ⅈ⋅π⋅n | n ∊ ℤ} should be ans and in second case _invert_real should return soln in real domain only (although invert_real works fine but I think it should be done in lower level functions), right ?
text:
```
In [ ]: Intersection(ImageSet(Lambda(n, 2*n*I*pi), S.Integers), S.Complexes)
Out[ ]: {2⋅ⅈ⋅π⋅n | n ∊ ℤ} ∩ ℂ

In [ ]: from sympy.solvers.solveset import  _invert_real
In [ ]: _invert_real(exp(x) + 8,FiniteSet(0), x)
Out[ ]: (x, {log(8) + ⅈ⋅π})

```
In first case directly ` {2⋅ⅈ⋅π⋅n | n ∊ ℤ}` should be ans and in second case `_invert_real`  should return soln in real domain only (although `invert_real` works fine but I think it should be done in lower level functions), right ?
